repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes some of https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4819 (although
there's a second issue about applying this more generally to binops).

It works by always generating a second utility code function with
a bint result type and substituting that out if needed. This is
on the basis that the coercion is likely to be sufficiently
common that the code generation is worth the effort

comment_data.body:
I find this slightly better.
```suggestion
                        (self.special_bool_cmp_function,
                         self.special_bool_cmp_utility_code,
                         self.special_bool_extra_args,
                         _) = result
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -13062,6 +13063,20 @@ def find_special_bool_compare_function(self, env, operand1, result_is_bool=False
                     self.special_bool_cmp_utility_code = UtilityCode.load_cached("StrEquals", "StringTools.c")
                     self.special_bool_cmp_function = "__Pyx_PyString_Equals"
                     return True
+                elif result_is_bool:
+                    from .Optimize import optimise_numeric_binop
+                    result = optimise_numeric_binop(
+                        "Eq" if self.operator == "==" else "Ne",
+                        self,
+                        PyrexTypes.c_bint_type,
+                        self.operand1,
+                        self.operand2
+                    )
+                    if result:
+                        self.special_bool_cmp_function = result[0]
+                        self.special_bool_cmp_utility_code = result[1]
+                        self.special_bool_extra_args = result[2]

comment_data.body:
Let's avoid using the same variable for two different things.
```suggestion
            special_bool_extra_args_result = ", ".join([
                extra_arg.result() for extra_arg in self.special_bool_extra_args
            ])
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -13111,14 +13126,19 @@ def generate_operation_code(self, code, result_code,
                 result2 = operand2.py_result()
             else:
                 result2 = operand2.result()
+            special_bool_extra_args_result = [
+                extra_arg.result() for extra_arg in self.special_bool_extra_args
+            ]
+            special_bool_extra_args_result = ", ".join(special_bool_extra_args_result)

comment_data.body:
This seems simpler (yes, I'm aware that this code was just moved around):
```suggestion
    is_float = numval.type.is_float
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4181,6 +4133,73 @@ def _inject_bint_default_argument(self, node, args, arg_index, default_value):
             args[arg_index] = args[arg_index].coerce_to_boolean(self.current_env())
 
 
+def optimise_numeric_binop(operator, node, ret_type, arg0, arg1):
+    """
+    Optimise math operators for (likely) float or small integer operations.
+    """
+    # When adding IntNode/FloatNode to something else, assume other operand is also numeric.
+    # Prefer constants on RHS as they allows better size control for some operators.
+    num_nodes = (ExprNodes.IntNode, ExprNodes.FloatNode)
+    if isinstance(arg1, num_nodes):
+        if arg0.type is not PyrexTypes.py_object_type:
+            return None
+        numval = arg1
+        arg_order = 'ObjC'
+    elif isinstance(arg0, num_nodes):
+        if arg1.type is not PyrexTypes.py_object_type:
+            return None
+        numval = arg0
+        arg_order = 'CObj'
+    else:
+        return None
+
+    if not numval.has_constant_result():
+        return None
+
+    is_float = isinstance(numval, ExprNodes.FloatNode)

comment_data.body: I undid this change (and added a brief explanatory comment) - numval seems to usually be a Python float type rather than a C float type so doesn't pass this check.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4181,6 +4133,73 @@ def _inject_bint_default_argument(self, node, args, arg_index, default_value):
             args[arg_index] = args[arg_index].coerce_to_boolean(self.current_env())
 
 
+def optimise_numeric_binop(operator, node, ret_type, arg0, arg1):
+    """
+    Optimise math operators for (likely) float or small integer operations.
+    """
+    # When adding IntNode/FloatNode to something else, assume other operand is also numeric.
+    # Prefer constants on RHS as they allows better size control for some operators.
+    num_nodes = (ExprNodes.IntNode, ExprNodes.FloatNode)
+    if isinstance(arg1, num_nodes):
+        if arg0.type is not PyrexTypes.py_object_type:
+            return None
+        numval = arg1
+        arg_order = 'ObjC'
+    elif isinstance(arg0, num_nodes):
+        if arg1.type is not PyrexTypes.py_object_type:
+            return None
+        numval = arg0
+        arg_order = 'CObj'
+    else:
+        return None
+
+    if not numval.has_constant_result():
+        return None
+
+    is_float = isinstance(numval, ExprNodes.FloatNode)

commit.message:
Avoid unnecessary coercion to Python on int comparisons

Fixes some of https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4819 (although
there's a second issue about applying this more generally to binops).

It works by always generating a second utility code function with
a bint result type and substituting that out if needed. This is
on the basis that the coercion is likely to be sufficiently
common that the code generation is worth the effort
Move some of the logic outside Optimize to PrimaryCmpNode

Revert "Handle case where optimization fails"

This reverts commit 634e66599c26a6953c18076ce61932f883d0480e.
Try to move optimization into CmpNode

Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Avoid unnecessary coercion to Python on int comparisons
